The verses are a square sixteen measures long followed by a two bar instrumental connector. The phrase structure is A-B-A-B-C-D-C-D-I harmony wise, melody wise it is more variant, also between the cycles. The rhythm track carries throughout a constant 8/8 pulsing while the lead vocal is flexibly rhythmized often using triplets. From here on the key is ambiguous. The F# and G chords weakly suggest a B minor key which is the relative minor key of the D Major key where we eventually arrive. The second verse adds tight backing vocal harmonies during the second subsection. The third verse that follows the solo omits the first eight measures. The instrumental closing phrase shifts the key up by one whole step. The arpeggios here are doubled with sampled vocal synths.

After the second chorus, we break into a slide guitar solo from Brian May. Brian solo’s over the chorus progression, even the first few notes quote the original lead vocal melody. The slide playing varies in tempo, tone, and range position. The distorted part of the solo is heavy with loud amplification. It returns to the quiet slide solo, before returning to the third verse.

The intro exposes the tonic chord arpeggiated in three different inversions. The synths play D minor, with the bass and chimes appearing on the last phrase. The second cycle is also introduced with a two-bar shortened variant of the intro with more chimes. The outro is a closer variant of the intro. The synth part goes D minor to D minor/F to D minor/A.

The chorus is in the key of D Major, and the first subsection of the chorus is the doubled-up title phrase, the second time extended with an extra measure that provides a place for the upbeat of the second subsection. During the second subsection, the harmony has no established center. The F chord doesn’t sound like either of a ♭III-of-D, IV-of-C, or the new tonic chord. The first chorus is followed by a short re-intro. The second chorus closes with a one-measure D minor chord which is followed by the opening D chord of the guitar solo by Brian May. The last chorus doubles up the last vocal phrase before the outro, with guitar  tremolo picked glissando’s and echoed vocal parts by Freddie Mercury.

The song starts off with many different tongue-in-cheek one-liners and different and humorous ways of phrasing “I’m going slightly mad”
Many of these lyrics were thought up by Mercury and his friend Peter Straker.
In his book “Mercury and Me”, Mercury’s partner Jim Hutton says

“Freddie set about with Peter trying to come up with a succession of goofy lyrics, each funnier than the last. He screamed when they came up with things like ‘I’m knitting with only one needle’ and ‘I’m driving on only three wheels these days’. But the master-stroke was: ‘I think I’m a banana tree’. Once that came out there was no stopping Freddie and Straker – they were then in full flow. I went to bed to fall asleep listening to their laughter wafting upstairs.”
